questions.question:
Question 1: During the swab collection for COVID-19 testing, the healthcare professional asks you to tilt 
your head approximately to what degree?
questions.explanation:
For collecting nasal/nasopharyngeal/oropharyngeal specimens for COVID-19 testing, a person’s 
head should be tilted back 70 degrees. Guidelines for specimen collection: • Use appropriate PPE and maintain proper infection control measures • Restricted entry to visitors or attendants during sample collection • Complete the requisition form for each specimen submitted • Proper disposal of all waste generated 1525 
Sold by @itachibot Recommended personal protective equipment (PPE) for the healthcare professional who is 
collecting the specimen or coming within 6 feet of the patient: • N95 or higher-level respirator (or facemask if a respirator is not available) • eye protection • gloves • gown

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is a false statement regarding sample collection for COVID-19 testing?

options.a: The nasal swab is placed in a different viral transport media tube as the throat swab.
options.b: Oropharyngeal sample is not collected using a calcium alginate swab.
options.c: Swab is rubbed over the tonsillar pillars and posterior oropharynx for oropharyngeal swab.
options.d: Swab is inserted parallel to the palate for nasopharyngeal swab.

questions.explanation:
The nasal swab is placed in the same viral transport media tube as the throat swab. Samples that can be used for COVID-19 testing are: • Throat and nasal swab • Oropharyngeal swab • Nasopharyngeal swab • Broncho-alveolar lavage • Endotracheal aspirate Combined throat and nasal swabs: • Tilt patient's head back 70 degrees. • Gently rotate the swab and insert less than one inch into the nostril. Rotate the swab several 
times against the nasal wall and repeat the same in the other nostril with the same swab. • Place the tip of the swab into the transport media tube and cut off the applicator. • For throat swab, take a second swab, insert into the mouth and swab the posterior pharynx and 
tonsillar areas. • Place the tip of the swab into the same tube and cut off the applicator tip. Oropharyngeal swab: • Tilt patient's head back 70 degrees. • Rub swab over both tonsillar pillars and posterior oropharynx and avoid touching the tongue, 
teeth, and gums. • Use only synthetic fiber swabs with plastic shafts. Avoid calcium alginate swabs and swabs with 
wooden shafts. • Place the swab immediately into sterile tubes with viral transport medium. Nasopharyngeal swab: • Tilt the patient's head back 70 degrees • Insert flexible swab through the nares parallel to the palate (not upwards) until resistance is 
encountered 1526 
Sold by @itachibot • Rub and roll the swab and leave it in place for several seconds to absorb secretions before 
removing • Place the swab immediately into sterile tubes with viral transport medium. Viral transport mediums: • Hanks balanced salt solution with Ca and Mg and heat inactivated fetal bovine serum, 
gentamicin and amphotericin B (most commonly used) • Sterile saline • Phosphate buffered saline-glycerol medium • Amies medium

questions.question:
Question 3: The specimens collected for COVID-19 testing should be transported to the lab at what 
temperatures?
questions.explanation:
Specimens collected for COVID-19 testing should be transported to the lab at a temperature of 2 
to 8 degrees C as per the WHO guidelines. The ICMR/NIV guidelines recommend 4 degrees C for 
transport to the laboratory. Both guidelines recommend storing specimens at -70°C or below if a delay in testing or shipping

questions.question:
Question 4: Which level of BSL (Biosafety level) facility is required during specimen handling for 
molecular testing of SARS CoV 2?
questions.explanation:
Specimen handling for molecular testing of SARS CoV 2 would require BSL-2 or equivalent 
facilities. Microbiology and pathology laboratories performing diagnostic tests on a stool or respiratory 
specimen should handle potential SARS-CoV specimens using Biosafety Level 2 (BSL-2). Virus 
culture and initial characterization of viral agents recovered in cultures requires minimum BSL-3 
facilities. Note: Biosafety levels include a specific combination of work practices, safety equipment, and 
facilities that are designed to minimize the exposure of workers and the environment to infectious 
agents. There are four biosafety levels. 1527 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: An elderly patient was rushed to the casualty following bouts of severe breathlessness. He 
reported a history of fever and cough for the past 3 days. On examination, his SpO2 was 85% 
and RR was 32/min. CT scan is shown below. What is the gold standard investigation for his 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario, along with CT showing bilateral multiple patchy consolidation and 
grid-like thickness of interlobular septa, is suggestive of COVID-19. The gold standard for its 
diagnosis is the identification of viral genome targets in the respiratory tract materials by reverse 
transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) during the first week of symptoms. RT-PCR involves the reverse transcription of the genetic material of the virus (RNA) to 
complementary DNA (cDNA), followed by amplification of some regions of the cDNA. Four 
regions of the SARS CoV2 genome are used as targets: • RdRp gene (RNA-dependent RNA polymerase) • Genes from structural proteins • E (virus envelope) • N (virus nucleocapsid), • ORF1ab gene (open reading frame 1a and 1b) CBNAAT (cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification test) uses small, chip-based, portable, 
battery-operated devices that detect target genetic material of SARS CoV2. Examples include 
TrueNat and Cepheid Xpert Xpress SARS CoV-2 Options A and B: Antibody testing- Antibodies of IgA, IgM, and IgG isotypes specific to different 
virus proteins are detected by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) or 
chemiluminescence immunoassays (CLIA). CLIA is more sensitive compared to ELISA. Option C: Rapid antigen test (RAT)- Antigen-based assays are used as point-of-care tests for early 
detection of SARS-CoV-2. They are used at the field level for early detection of infection and quick 
containment. Most of such tests have relatively moderate sensitivity but high specificity. They are 
used for diagnosis along with RT-PCR.

questions.question: Question 6: Choose the correct statement regarding testing of COVID-19:

options.b: All pregnant women must be tested for COVID-19 in the first trimester.
options.c: No individual can voluntarily subject themselves to COVID-19 test.
options.d: A single positive RT-PCR test is considered confirmatory without repeat testing.

questions.explanation:
A single RT-PCR/TrueNat/CBNAAT/RAT positive is considered confirmatory without repeat 
testing. If symptoms develop following a negative RAT, a repeat RAT or RT-PCR should be done. Routine surveillance in containment zones and screening at points of entry for all symptomatic 
cases including: • Healthcare and frontline workers • Direct and high-risk contacts and individuals Routine surveillance in non-containment areas for all symptomatic cases including: • History of international travel in the last 14 days • Contacts of a laboratory-confirmed case • Healthcare and frontline workers involved in containment and mitigation activities 1528 
Sold by @itachibot • Returnees and migrants within 7 days of illness • All asymptomatic high-risk contacts In hospital settings for all symptomatic cases including: • All patients of Severe Acute Respiratory Infection (SARI) • Patients presenting in a healthcare setting • Neonates presenting with acute respiratory/sepsis-like illness • Patients with atypical manifestations (stroke, encephalitis, hemoptysis, Guillain Barre Syndrome 
etc.) based on the doctor's discretion • All pregnant women in/near labor hospitalized for delivery • Asymptomatic high-risk patients who are hospitalized or seeking immediate hospitalization (eg. 
immune compromise, malignancy, transplant, chronic comorbidities, elderly > 65 years) Testing on-demand for all individuals: • Traveling to countries/states mandating negative COVID-19 test at the point of entry • Who wish to get themselves tested

questions.question:
Question 7: A woman, whose husband has tested positive for COVID-19, comes to the clinic with a 
negative report on the rapid antigen test. She is currently asymptomatic. What will be the 
next step?

options.a: Retest with rapid antigen test after 5 days
options.d: Retest with RT-PCR if symptoms develop

questions.explanation:
Asymptomatic individuals with a negative rapid antigen test (RAT) need to be retested only if they 
develop symptoms of COVID-19 such as cough, fever, and difficulty in breathing. Rapid antigen test, when positive, is reported as positive in both symptomatic and asymptomatic 
patients. When the test is negative, the patient is retested with another RAT or RT-PCR only if the 
patient is symptomatic.

questions.question:
Question 8: A man presents to the flu clinic with complaints of fever and sore throat for the past 4 days. 
COVID-19 is suspected and a paper-based test kit as shown below is used for testing. Identify 
the test.
questions.explanation:
The paper-based Covid-19 test kit developed by CSIR and IGIB and approved by the Drugs 
Controller General of India (DCGI) is named FELUDA. FELUDA is an acronym for FNCAS9 Editor Linked Uniform Detection Assay. The name is 
inspired by a fictitious detective character in novels written by Satyajit Ray. FELUDA uses CRISPR-Cas9 technology (CRISPR = Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short 
Palindromic Repeats). The CRISPR technology uses a highly specific CAS9 protein to find and 
bind to the target Covid signature. This is then coupled with paper-strip chemistry to elicit a visual 
readout on a paper strip. It is a very affordable, sensitive (96%), and specific (98%) strip test 
which can detect viral genetic material within 45 minutes.

and NIV?
questions.explanation:
1529 
Sold by @itachibot COVID Kavach ELISA is an indigenous ELISA test kit for COVID-19 antibody detection developed 
by ICMR Delhi and NIV Pune. It is reported to have a 98.7% sensitivity and 100% specificity and testing is possible even at the 
district level. As the ELISA kit has an inactivated virus, only minimal biosafety and biosecurity 
requirements as compared to the real-time RT-PCR test. IgG antibodies usually start appearing after two weeks of the onset of infection. Therefore, the IgG 
test is not useful for detecting acute infection. IgG based antibody tests are used in 
sero-surveillance of the population.

questions.question: Question 10: What is least likely to be seen in a patient suspected of COVID-19?
questions.explanation:
Lymphocytosis is least likely to be seen in a patient with COVID-19. On the contrary, lymphopenia 
is likely to be seen. Common laboratory abnormalities seen in COVID-19 are: • Lymphopenia • Mild thrombocytopenia • Elevated aminotransaminase levels • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase levels • Elevated inflammatory markers - eg, ferritin, C-reactive protein, and erythrocyte sedimentation 
rate • Markers of a hypercoagulable state - high fibrinogen, high D-dimer levels, increased fibrin 
degradation products, prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin 
time (aPTT) The degree of these abnormalities tends to correlate with disease severity.

questions.question: Question 11: What is the most commonly seen pattern in chest CT of patients affected with COVID-19?
questions.explanation:
Ground glass opacity (GGO) is the most commonly seen pattern in chest CT of patients with 
COVID-19. Some of the typical features seen in the CT scans of COVID-19 patients include: • Ground glass opacities • Consolidation • Air bronchograms • Interlobular septal thickenings • Visible intralobular lines (crazy-paving pattern) • Reversed halo sign 1530 
Sold by @itachibot The image below shows an axial CT scan with multiple patchy areas of pure ground-glass 
opacities. GGO are hazy areas with slightly increased density in the lungs without obscuration of 
underlying bronchial and vascular margins. The image given below shows a CT scan with bilateral GGO in the lower lobe and an air 
bronchogram (arrow) in the left subpleural area. Air bronchograms appear like air-filled bronchi 
within a highly attenuated parenchymal background. These are dilated bronchi filled with mucus 
plugs and do not truly contain air. The image given below shows a CT scan with multiple consolidation areas and interlobular septal 
thickening (arrows) in both lungs. The pulmonary interstitial structures such as interlobular septa 
and intralobular lines can thicken and manifest as small linear opacities. 1531 
Sold by @itachibot The image given below shows a CT scan with crazy-paving pattern (circled area). It is defined as 
the presence of GGOs with superimposed interlobular septal thickening giving the appearance of 
irregular paving stones. The image given below shows a CT scan with multiple lesions with reversed halo sign 
(arrows). The reversed halo sign or atoll sign is the presence of a ring-like area of consolidation 
with a superimposed rounded GGO. 1532 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: Increased concentrations of all of the following are poor prognostic markers in a COVID-19 
patient except:
questions.explanation:
Glycosylated ferritin is decreased in severe COVID-19 illness and hence, it is not a poor prognostic 
marker. Interestingly, in contrast to ferritin which is actually elevated in individuals with COVID 19, the 
glycosylated ferritin is decreased. It is a potentially sensitive biomarker that can better 
discriminate severe COVID than ferritin alone. Increased levels of the following laboratory markers is associated with poorer outcomes: • D-dimer • C-reactive protein • Lactate dehydrogenase • Cardiac troponin • Ferritin • Creatinine phosphokinase

questions.question:
Question 13: 1524 
Sold by @itachibot Which inflammatory marker is of prognostic significance in COVID-19 patients?
questions.explanation:
Elevated pro-inflammatory cytokines like interleukin-6 (IL-6) are associated with critical and fatal 
COVID-19. It is specifically useful in predicting prognosis of such patients. Increased levels of the following laboratory markers are associated with poorer outcomes: • D-dimer • C-reactive protein • Lactate dehydrogenase 1533 
Sold by @itachibot • Cardiac troponin • Ferritin • Creatinine phosphokinase Options B, C and D: Inflammatory markers associated with increased severity of COVID-19 are: • PCT (procalcitonin test) • ESR • WBC • LMR (lymphocyte/mean platelet volume ratio) • HsCRP (high-sensitivity C-reactive protein) • NLR (neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio) 1534
